Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t) = x(t) + iy(t)\\) governed by a set of differential equations \\(\\dot{x} = Ax\\) and \\(\\dot{y} = By\\), where A and B are constant matrices. We explore the effect of an integral transformation \\(T(z) = \\int_0^t e^{Ct'}z(t')\\, dt'\\), where C is also a constant matrix and t is the time variable.

Is it possible to precisely recover the original complex function \\(z_0\\) after observing \\(z(t)\\) at t = T without knowing whether the transformation \\(T(z)\\) was applied?
Explanation: Without clear information about the application or non-application of \\(T(z)\\), and given the integral's effect over the complex function, multiple initial conditions could yield the same result at t = T. The indeterminate nature of back-tracking an integral amplitude modulation makes it difficult.
